body:
A quick check shows that changing `(.*?)` to `\d+` and `[.]` to `\.` does not parse the regexp at all.

```
> var ua = 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux i686) AppleWebKit/534.34 (KHTML, like Gecko) rekonq/1.0 Safari/534.34'
> var regex = '(rekonq)/(.*?)[.](.*?) Safari';
> var m = ua.match(new RegExp(regex))
> m
[ 'rekonq/1.0 Safari',
  'rekonq',
  '1',
  '0',
  index: 69,
  input: 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux i686) AppleWebKit/534.34 (KHTML, like Gecko) rekonq/1.0 Safari/534.34' ]
> var regex2 = '(rekonq)/(\d+)\.(\d+) Safari';
> var m2 = ua.match(new RegExp(regex2))
> m2
null
```
I refactored it only for sake of readability. Nothing special. Will revert if you favor the `for` loop.
Will do.
Will do.

body: Maybe add example for device as well.
Missing newline at EOF.

I'm not sure this is a good idea. [`empty()`](http://php.net/empty empty) is considered harmful. What was wrong with null? I'd recommend changing to `$ua !== null` as opposed to opening it up further. Otherwise it can cause some really strange situations where a value is passed and it ends up ignoring it completely in favour of the lobal http user agent. empty is very very tolerant, even worse than PHP's boolean false casting (such as string "0".

When for some reason `UA::parse()` is called with an empty string or "0", I would expect it to return an object with all the properties in some kind of generic state, not a fully parsed object for the global http user agent.

This is a nice improvement, thanks! I found it very annoying when including this library in other libraries that are also used from the command-line interface, that even when it was merely included somewhere, it would take over and start outputting random messages in the script about "Must use -get", even when that wasn't at all appropiate. Thanks!

There's nothing inherently harmful about `empty()`; it's much clearer and less ambiguous than saying `$ua ?` (ternary operators are infamous for obfuscation), and _none_ of the things that are considered empty are viable user agent strings, so making all of them qualify for that default response seems sensible to me. Why call the function if you don't want it to parse something? It's like complaining that echo produces output! If you want some kind of placeholder response, then a separate function would be appropriate to request it explicitly rather than relying on some peculiar edge-case behaviour; there's no need to try and squeeze everything through one interface. The current implementation will attempt every defined regex to identify a non-existent UA string - why bother going to all that effort to get a placeholder?
That said, a more elegant solution to avoid surprise as you mention might be to drop the null/blank/empty case altogether (or make it return a generic response directly) and always use parse _only_ for an explicitly supplied UA string, and have a separate parseCurrent function for the global user agent.
That's what I was thinking! A library should be a library and not try to be anything else! The option handling is a mess anyway, it should be using getopt.

Thanks for the feedback, guys. This was a pseudo-port that was originally meant for my own specific use case. I don't think I was clear enough about that when it got rolled into the overall project. I'm now going to work to fit the more general needs.

body: This stuff belongs in a separate PR.
Why null?
If there is no match for a device, so what to add here? "Unknown"? "null" fit better with the test set.
is considered.
Shouldn't we make it m[2] instead (for consistency)?

Don't think so. m[1] is seen as a fallback if no x_replacement is given for the matched user_agent_string. As we could expect that a regex at least has one match we should leave it m[1].
In nearly all cases we have a x_replacement given so for these cases the fallback should not be issued.
I would actually use a named pattern here. Something like `'|\\$(?<replacementKey>\d)|'`. Than you can access it with  `$m['replacementKey']`.
Thanks for your comment. Last commit contains your recommended changes.
The braces are superfluous. For the comparison, let’s use strict comparison `!=='.
Just `return empty($replacement) ? null : $replacement;` with a newline before.
Either use `sprintf("Family: %s !== %s", $family, $result->device->family)` or `'family: ' . $family . ' !== ' . $result->device->family`.
Superfluous newline.

Variable should be camelCase, not underscore_case. Additionally: `$mr_default` does not really tell me what it means. Can only guess, `$multiReplaceDefault`? If the latter, why not just call it `$deviceModelDefault`?
Please add a newline above `$replacement =`.
